--- title: "ACS Variables" description: | An overview of Census ACS variables, particularly related to housing. categories: - census - housing - tidycensus - R image: "img/variables.png" date: "2021-12-24" date-modified: "2025-05-13" --- The R `tidycensus` package is an amazingly simple way to access Census data.[^1] When you use the package to call Census data, you need to know the variable code for the table or piece of data you're trying to find. The `load_variables()` function allows you to quickly see all variables released in a given year by a survey or program. Census data is well organized and mostly consistent across years.[^2] This page is meant to help sort through the tens of thousands of variables to find the information you need. [^1]: The `tidycensus` package was created by [Kyle Walker](https://twitter.com/kyle_e_walker), and he also published an amazingly helpful book [Analyzing US Census Data](https://walker-data.com/census-r/index.html), which I strongly recommend for anyone interested in accessing Census data with R. [^2]: The Census Bureau releases [information](https://www.census.gov/data/developers/data-sets/acs-1year.2021.html) on which variables have changed from the previous year. # ACS Variables Variables for the ACS Detailed Tables all begin with the same pattern: a letter (B or C) followed by five digits. The first two digits correspond to a general topic of information, defined in the table below. Variables that start with "C" correspond to a "B" table, but provide more condensed information, such as fewer age groups or income categories. These can be useful when you feel like a graph has too much info and needs to be simplified. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: # Housing Variables Housing variables start with "B25", or "C25" for condensed versions. Sometimes a specific topic will have a lot of different subvariables. For instance, information on tenure (whether a household rents or owns) can be broken down by age, what year the structure was built, etc. I created a directory tree as a simple way to visualize how Census variable relate to each other. The following tree shows top-level ACS 1-Year variables related to housing. The variables that start with "B" are usually also present in the 5-Year ACS. ::: {.cell .column-page-right} ```{.zsh .cell-code} . ├── Age-Of-Householder │   ├── C25055-(2005-2023) │   ├── │   └── C25004-(2005-2023) ├── Vacant-Current-Residence-Elsewhere │   └── B25005-(2005-2023) ├── Value │   ├── B25075-(2005-2023) │   └── C25075-(2006-2023) └── Year-Structure-Built └── B25034-(2005-2023) 300 directories, 0 files ``` ::: # How to make the tree ## R First, load the tidyverse and tidycensus packages. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(tidycensus) ``` ::: Use the `load_variables()` function to get Census variables. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # acs1 data is available from 2005-2023, excluding 2020 years <- c(2005:2019, 2021:2023) # function to load variables for each year, filter for housing get_hsg_vars <- function(year) { load_variables(year, "acs1") |> filter(str_starts(name, "^[BC]25")) |> mutate(year = {{ year }}) } # Get variables for all years all_hsg_vars <- map(years, get_hsg_vars) |> list_rbind() ``` ::: Narrow for housing variables and clean up. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Get the top level variables top_hsg_vars <- all_hsg_vars |> filter(str_detect(name, "_001$"), #' only top-level variables !str_detect(name, "[:alpha:]_"), #' omit race variables !str_detect(label, "Estimate!!Aggregate")) |> #' omit aggregates, medians, etc. mutate( concept = str_replace_all(concept, c( "\\b20\\d{2}\\b" = "ACSYEAR", "INCOME THE PAST 12 MONTHS" = "INCOME IN THE PAST 12 MONTHS") ) |> str_to_title() ) |> select(year, name, concept) ``` ::: Use the 2012 ACS to fill in missing variable names for the 2010 and 2011 surveys. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} top_hsg_vars_fix <- top_hsg_vars |> group_by(name) |> fill(concept, .direction = "up") |> ungroup() |> mutate(concept = case_when( is.na(concept) & name == "B25028_001" ~ "Tenure By Year Structure Built", is.na(concept) & name == "B25029_001" ~ "Tenure By Year Householder Moved Into Unit", .default = concept )) ``` ::: Create a column for the year range. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} hsg_var_years <- top_hsg_vars_fix |> mutate(concept = str_remove_all(concept, "\\(.*\\)")) |> mutate( year_range = case_when( min(year) != max(year) ~ paste0("(", min(year), "-", max(year), ")"), .default = paste0("(", min(year), ")") ), .by = c("name", "concept")) |> select(-year) |> distinct() ``` ::: Format for the command line. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} v_acs1 <- hsg_var_years |> mutate( concept = str_replace_all(concept, "-(?=[:alpha:])", " ") |> str_remove_all("[:punct:]") |> str_squish() |> str_replace_all(" By ", "/"), name = str_remove(name, "_001") ) |> unite(col = "name", name, year_range, sep = "-", na.rm = TRUE) |> unite(col = "fileStr", concept, name, sep = "/", na.rm = TRUE) |> mutate(fileStr = str_replace_all(fileStr, "\\s", "-"), fileStr = str_replace_all(fileStr, "-{2,}", "-")) |> pull(fileStr) write_lines(v_acs1, file = "~/Documents/v_acs1.txt") ``` ::: To make the tree, we will convert this text file to a directory structure. ## Command Line In the terminal, make a new directory to house your Census tree. ``` zsh mkdir ~/Documents/census-vars cd Documents/census-vars ``` Convert the text file to a file directory using the following code. ``` zsh xargs -I {} mkdir -p "{}" < "../v_acs1.txt" ``` Finally, create a tree of the file directory. Note: requires the [tree](https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/tree#default) package. ``` zsh tree > "../v_acs1_tree.txt" ``` The output is the tree above.
